DOC.HEAD: Glemp Wishes Lawmakers Strength During First Parliament Visit
DOC.TEXT: Primate Jozef Glemp today paid tribute to lawmakers of all political persuasions during the first visit by a Poland's Roman Catholic leader to Parliament in the country's postwar history. Lawmakers greeted Glemp with Christmas carols. His visit was another sign of the changes in Poland's government since Solidarity-backed candidates trounced Communist parliamentary candidates and joined with other parties to form the East bloc's first government led by non-Communists. Similar changes occurred in recent months in East Germany and Czechoslovakia, and democratic reforms have spread through Bulgaria, Hungary and Romania. Glemp met with senators and members of the Sejm, as the lower house of Parliament is called, during a break in a heated debate over amendments to the constitution and an eventual change in the country's national emblem. ``I wish you enough strength for the coming year and that the link between the nation and the Parliament will become stronger and meet with greater understanding,'' he said. Throughout the morning, lawmakers debated the constitutional amendments, especially one that would eliminate a clause giving the Communist Party the leading role in state affairs as well as a proposed change that would add a crown to the national emblem. The package of constitutional amendments would also restore the historical name of the country to the prewar Republic of Poland instead of the Communist-imposed People's Republic of Poland. ``We shall soon say goodbye to 1989,'' said Edward Rzepa, a deputy from the Solidarity caucus. ``It seems it is the most appropriate moment to give society a long-expected gift _ a new constitution.'' The constitutional amendments, proposed by the Solidarity caucus, are designed to eliminate or change sections inconsistent with new democratic reforms until a completely new constitution can be written.
